Navigate to other release versions of Doxee Platform Process Engine

[6.6](https://docs.doxee.com/docs/en/process-engine-6-6)

[6.7](https://docs.doxee.com/docs/en/process-engine-6-7)

![](data:image/png;base64,)Figure 24. Process Execution State Diagram

> Note

The TERMINATED state can also be reached from READY and WAITING, it is only connected to RUNNING in the diagram for better readability.

To execute a process, its process definition must be instantiated. This results in a process instance, which is the representation of the process at runtime. Each process instance has a unique ID and a state, which changes during the process’s lifetime.

> Note

When the implied meaning is clear from the context, both process definitions and process instances may be referred to simply as processes in this documentation.

The figure [Process Execution State Diagram](/docs/chapter-8-the-process-lifecycle#image-link) shows the potential flow between the states of a process instance. After instantiation the state is CREATED, meaning that the process instance exists but is not yet ready for execution. A continueProcess call sets the state to READY. Now the Process Engine can execute the process as soon as it has capacity. While doing so the state is set to RUNNING. If the Engine interrupts execution, the state returns to READY and can be taken up again any time. If the process triggers a wait state, the process instance state is set to WAITING and execution will not continue until the wait state signals that it is done. If a running process runs into an error, the state is set to FAILED and the execution is done. Once a running process reaches an end element, the state is set to FINISHED and the execution is done. If the user terminates a process which is READY, RUNNING or WAITING, the state is set to TERMINATED and the execution is done.

READY and RUNNING are called active states. All other states are classified as non-active states.

FINISHED, TERMINATED and FAILED are called end states. A process execution which reaches one of these states is considered done and will not change its state again.

A process instance which is in an end state will be kept in the Engine’s list of process instances until a user fetches an execution snapshot of the finished process. Once such a snapshot is returned to a client, it is purged and no longer available for querying. If a user wants to retrieve a snapshot of a finished instance without purging it, the PEEK parameter can be included when calling the Process Engine.

## Health
In addition to the execution state, a process instance has a health status. During a normal process lifecycle the health should always be OK. The health will change if there are problems with the process instance which cause it not to be executable anymore. The health can be one of the following values:

- OK: The instance is in a consistent state.

- LOST: The instance has been lost while running. This can happen if the instance is executed by a Process Engine which crashes, is shut down in an unclean way or unexpectedly loses the connection to its cluster. It means that some actions might have been executed after the last persisted state of the instance. In the cluster it also means that two nodes might have made concurrent changes to the instance.

- BROKEN: There is some missing or inconsistent information which prevents the instance from being executed. It is possible to restore broken instances so they can be executed again.

- DEFINITION_CONFLICT: There is a problem with the process definition. Reloading the process definition might solve the issue.

- CORRUPT: The instance is missing or lacking some crucial parts. This can happen for example if the instance was supposed to be persisted but could not be restored properly. A corrupt instance is dead and cannot be repaired. A corrupt instance might also lack some of the information which is usually available (creation time, etc.).

- KILLED: The instance has been killed and cannot continue.

[Error Health Mapping](/doxee-platform/docs/6-6-process-engine-user-guide-exception-handling#error-health-mapping) may cause processes to change their health state instead of failing outright. For example, authentication errors may put a process into a BROKEN health state, allowing it to be resumed once updated credentials have been provided.

## Online and Offline Instances
A process can be paused manually at any time by setting its online state to offline. This will set the process back to READY if is is currently RUNNING and also prevent it to switch to RUNNING even if it is in the READY state.

If a process instance reaches a breakpoint that has been set with the *setBreakpoint* operation, it will automatically change its state to offline and remain offline until it is explicitly set online.

In contrast, an execution enters a WAITING state when the process itself waits for a wait state to be triggered. In that case, the instance will be set back to READY as soon as the wait state signals that the requested event has occurred, and the process can continue.

If a process is both WAITING and offline, it will not continue running until both its wait state has fired and its state has been set back to online. If the wait state fires before the process has been set to online, it will remain offline in the READY state.

## Process Execution Snapshots
The status of a process instance at a given time is called a process execution snapshot. Such a snapshot contains all data relevant for the execution, including:

- The process execution ID

- The ID of the current element, if any. For paused and waiting processes, this is the element where execution will continue when the process wakes up.

- The process definition URL

- Whether the instance is online or not

- The current execution state

- Potentially a human readable message about the process state, e.g. an error message if the execution has failed

- The health status of the instance

- Potentially a human readable message about the health status

- The owner of the instance

- The name of the thread pool to which the instance has been assigned

- The time at which the process was instantiated

- The time at which the process was started (if it has already been started)

- The time at which the process has finished (if it has reached an end state)

- The time at which the snapshot was taken

- A number showing how often the execution state has changed for the instance

- The process pipeline if it is requested when querying the snapshot

- For a failed process, the exception(s) that caused it to fail

- A list of permissions set for the instance

As long as a process instance exists, clients can query snapshots to retrieve this data.

## Persistence
If a persistence storage has been configured, a process’s current state will periodically be written to the storage. This allows processes to continue even after shutting down and restarting the Process Engine. Along with a process’s snapshot data, its process definition is persisted as well, so that the process will continue in its original configuration even if the IPD file changes while the process instance is active. To update a process instance’s definition to a newer version stored in an IPD file, the *reload* operation can be used. If the new definition is compatible with the previous one used by the process instance, the instance will continue running normally.

## Process Resources
Process resources are entities that are created by a process and bound to the lifecycle of that process, but may not managed by the Process Engine and may even reside outside of the Process Engine (possibly even on another system).

A process resource can be released manually using the `releaseResource` activity. When a process reaches an end state, all its remaining resources are released automatically.

Some resource types may not be persistable, or may be bound to the system on which they were created. A process holding one or more such instances may be *locked*, preventing it from being uncached or relocated in a cluster. Locked processes may increase the memory footprint of the Process Engine, because they have to be kept in memory even while they are not running. They may also lose data if the Process Engine is shut down before they are finished. To keep the duration during which a process is locked as short as possible, such resources should be released via the releaseResource activity as soon as they are no longer used.

The following resource types are currently used by the Process Engine:

**Temp files**

Temporary files and directories, as created e.g. by the `createTempFile` activity. These are local and not persistable and therefore cause the process to be locked.

**Wait states**

Created by wait state elements. Wait states are persistable and therefore do not add restrictions to their processes.

## Volatile Processes
Volatile processes are processes that cannot be persisted, typically because they have been assigned to a thread pool on which persistence has been disabled.

A volatile process only writes very limited data to the storage (as required for basic Process Engine functionality), but does not persist any runtime data or user credentials. It is always kept in memory and will be lost if the Process Engine is shut down before it is finished. In a cluster environment, volatile processes are locked to the engine node on which they were instantiated.
